articles.headline: Texas Firm Accused of $8 Billion Fraud
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it could not account for $8 billion in assets held by the Stanford Financial Group.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it could not account for $8 billion in assets held by the Stanford Financial Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  In Texas, Robert Allen Stanford was just another wealthy financier.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss, Phillip L. Zweig and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Automakers Seek $14 Billion More, Vowing Deep Cuts
articles.snippet: General Motors and Chrysler promised to make further cuts, in hopes of lightening their bloated cost structures amid a dismal market for new car sales.
articles.abstract: General Motors and Chrysler promised to make further cuts, in hopes of lightening their bloated cost structures amid a dismal market for new car sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The price tag for bailing out General Motors and Chrysler jumped by another $14 billion Tuesday, to $39 billion, with the two automakers saying they would need the additional aid from the federal government to remain solvent.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Starbucks Coffee, Now in Instant
articles.snippet: The company’s move to sell instant coffee is taking place as Starbucks is battling for growth as consumers rein in spending.
articles.abstract: The company’s move to sell instant coffee is taking place as Starbucks is battling for growth as consumers rein in spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Howard Schultz’s 1997 book about developing Starbucks, he wrote, “Nothing pains me more than hearing critics compare Starbucks to a chain of discount stores or fast-food operations.”

articles.headline: A Painful Departure for G.M. Brands
articles.snippet: General Motors’ expansive lineup was once its primary weapon, but it plans to cut four brands.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ expansive lineup was once its primary weapon, but it plans to cut four brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The brand that was once hailed as an important part of the future of General Motors now will be part of its past.

articles.headline: Obama Takes On Auto Crisis Without a ‘Czar’
articles.snippet: The scope and reach that the Obama administration will have in the nation’s auto industry is unprecedented.
articles.abstract: The scope and reach that the Obama administration will have in the nation’s auto industry is unprecedented.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s decision to act as his own “car czar” means that in the next few months he faces decisions no American president has made since the invention of the automobile.

articles.headline: Bailout Likely to Focus on Most Afflicted Homeowners
articles.snippet: A key to understanding the housing bailout is that two very different groups of homeowners face foreclosure.
articles.abstract: A key to understanding the housing bailout is that two very different groups of homeowners face foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long-awaited housing bailout will finally be announced on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Alaska Is a Frontier for Green Power
articles.snippet: Alaska is fast becoming an experiment in oil-state support for renewable energy.
articles.abstract: Alaska is fast becoming an experiment in oil-state support for renewable energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKSOOK BAY, Alaska  Beyond the fishing boats, the snug homes and the tanks of diesel fuel marking this Eskimo village on the Bering Sea, three huge wind turbines tower over the tundra. Their blades spin slowly in a breeze cold enough to freeze skin.

articles.headline: Facebook Withdraws Changes in Data Use
articles.snippet: After a wave of protests, Facebook said it would withdraw changes to its terms of service concerning the data supplied by users.
articles.abstract: After a wave of protests, Facebook said it would withdraw changes to its terms of service concerning the data supplied by users.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook, the popular social networking site where people share photos and personal updates with friends and acquaintances, lost some face on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: $275 Billion Plan Seeks to Address Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: President Obama unveiled a plan intended to help as many as 9 million people stay in their homes.
articles.abstract: President Obama unveiled a plan intended to help as many as 9 million people stay in their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — President Obama announced a plan on Wednesday to help as many as nine million American homeowners refinance their mortgages or avert foreclosure, saying that it would shore up housing prices, stabilize neighborhoods and slow a downward spiral that was “unraveling homeownership, the middle class and the American Dream itself.”
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Edmund L. Andrews
